title: English Writing 05
author: loving-English Anastasia
content:
exhaust, expose


How does the book look like?
How to get one?Buy it!


 Â´â—_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ Ù©( â€˜Ï‰â€™ )Ùˆ  get! _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _â—`
1. exhaust-1. If something exhausts you, it makes you so tired, either physically or mentally, that you have no energyleft.Eg. He took to walk long distances in an attempt to physically exhaust himself.
    The long journey exhausted the children.-2. If you exhaust something such as money or food, you use or finish it all.Eg. We have exhausted all our material resources.
    They said that food supplies were almost exhausted.-3. If you exhausted a subject or topic, you have talked about it so much that there is nothing more to say about it.Eg. She and Chantal must have exhausted the subject of babies and clothes.
    We seem to have exhausted this topic of conversation(=we have nothing new to say about it).-4. Exhaust is the gas or steam that is produced when the engine of a vehicle is running.Eg. the exhaust from a car engine
    The city's streets are filthy and choked with exhaust fumes.
    the concentration of car exhaust in the Los Angeles areaã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘Being a teacher is not easy. After a full dayâ€™s teaching, which normally exhausts them, teachers still have to answer studentsâ€™ questions at home.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘Whenever people start to worry that our limited energy resources is about to be exhausted, new energy tachnologies emerge, which have a profound impact on the economy.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘Some people believe that resources on earth are so bountiful that they are almost unlimited, but in reality we are in danger of exhausting the worldâ€™s oil supply.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘Some cultures are in danger of dying out, even though their supporters have exhausted all the methods possible to preserve them.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘The government has exhausted the subject of juvenile delinquency before introducing a new law on it.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘Surprisingly, walking long distances on weekends to exhaust yourself is a good way to relax, both mentally and physically.ã€åˆä½œã€‘Disputed with others in the workplace can be exhausting, which makes efficient and effective work impossible.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘Sometimes we laugh at people who refuse to give up even through they seem to have exhausted all the possibilities, but it is normally those people who change the world.
2. expose-1. If someone is exposed to something dangerous or unpleasant, they are put in a situation in which it might affect them.Eg. They had not been exposed to most disease common to urban populations.
    A wise mother never exposes her children  to the slightest possibility of danger.   -2. If someone is exposed to an idea or feeling, usually a new one, they are given experience of it, or introduced to it.Eg. local people who've not been exposed to glimpses of Western life before.
    These units exposed children to many viewpoints of a given issue.ã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘Education that respects individuality exposes children to a variety of knowledge beyond the content of the test, which is conductive to cultivation their creativety and independent learning ability.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘As technology develops, we are witnessing technologyâ€™s increasing ability to expose peopleâ€™s privacy.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘Because we are constantly exxposed to the air, we cannot imagine how terrible life will be if air quality is not guaranteed.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘After the phenomenon of cashing in on traditional culture was exposed, the excessive commercial development of ethnic minority villages received much attention in the press.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘When it comes to internet use, the biggest fear among parents is that their children may be exposed to pornography.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘Although the concentration of air pollutants is not high, if people are exposed to them for a long time, they will be at higher risk of lung cancer.ã€åˆä½œã€‘Although we are often exposed to theories about how to cooperate with others, we may still feel overwhelmed when facing differences.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘If you want to become successful, you should expose yourself to those who are more successful than you.

title: English Writing 04
author: loving-English Anastasia
content:
exaggerate, exclude


How does the book look like?
How to get one?Buy it!


 Â´â—_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ Ù©( â€˜Ï‰â€™ )Ùˆ  get! _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _â—`
1. exaggerate- If you exaggerate, you indicate that something is, for example, worse or more important than it really is.Eg. Sheila admitted that she did sometimes exaggerate the demands of her job.
    The threat of attack has been greatly exaggerated.
    Newspapers were accused of exaggerating the danger of the virus.
    I'm sure the government is exaggerating the size of the problem.
    The extent of the damage has been exaggerated.ã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘The importance of education cannot be exaggerated: it is crucial to a countryâ€™s future.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘There are always some people who exaggerate the problems brought by technology, while ignoring the benefits it brings.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘Some people believe that the harmful effects of global warming heve been greatly exaggerated, and that cutting carbon emissions is of secondary importance.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘Cultual differences cannot be exaggerated. What is acceptable in one culture may be offensive in another.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘The media tend to exaggerate the crime problem, because it is a good way to attract peopleâ€™s attention, but it also makes people feel that crime is commonplace.This can lead to paranoia, pessimism and a general lack of trust in society.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘The importance of sleep cannot be exaggerated. It is the easiest and most efficient way of maintaining good mental and physical health.ã€åˆä½œã€‘People who like to exaggerate their own role will find it difficult to get along with their teammates.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘People sometimes exaggerate the difficulties they face, which creates unnecessary burdens on them and prevents them from making serious efforts to pursue their goals. 
2. exclude-1. If you exclude someone from a place or activity, you prevent them from entering it or taking part in it.Eg. The Academy excluded women from its classes.
    The army should be excluded from political life.
    Many of the youngsters feel excluded.-2. If you exclude something that has some connection with what you are doing, you deliberately do not use it or consider it.Eg. They eat only plant foods, and take care to exclude animal products from other areas of their lives.
    In some schools, Christmas carols are being modefied to exclude any reference to Christ.
    an immigration policy that excludes undesirablesã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘Students should learn to respect others and obey the rules, or they may be excluded from school.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘The development of science and technology requires the joint efforts of the global community, so countries should not be excluded from international science programs for economic or religious reasons.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘In order to protect animals, some people eat only fruits and vegetables and exclude animal products from other areas of their lives.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘In the past, women had fewer rights than men. For example, female students used to be excluded from most schools.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘In some crime-ridden areas teenagers have to choose between joining a gang or being excluded or even bullied by their peers.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘Some people exclude meat from their daily diet in order to lose weight, but this will do harm to their health.ã€åˆä½œã€‘Those who lack team spirit should be excluded from the team because they will reduce the efficiency of the entire team.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘Visionary leaders do not exclude the possibility of failure when thinking about future plans, and they make preparations for such scenarios.

title: English Writing 03
author: loving-English Anastasia
content:
endure, erode


How does the book look like?
How to get one?Buy it!


 Â´â—_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ Ù©( â€˜Ï‰â€™ )Ùˆ  get! _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _â—`
1. endure-1. If you endure a painful or difficult situation, you experience it and do not avoid it or give up, usually because you cannot.Eg. The company endure heavy financial losses.
    We had to endure a nine-hour delay at the airport.
    She's already had to endure three painful operations on her leg.
    We seek the truth, and will endure the consequences.
    He can't endure criticism.-2. If something endures, it continues to exist without any loss in quality or importance.Eg. Somehow the language endures and continues to survive.
    The political system established in 1400 endures until about 1650.
    friendships which endure over many years
    His work will endure for centuries.ã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘Exam-oriented education has endured since the resumption of the college entrance exam, and educators believe that it is time to promote quality education.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘ Due to the lack of supervision of online comments, many innocent people are enduring cyberbullying and have nowhere to complain.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘Peopleâ€™s efforts to cope with air pollution have endured for many years, and they have indeed achieved remarkable results.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘There have been countless wars and disasters in Chinaâ€™s history, but traditional Chinese culture endured and moved forward.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘Many people who commit crimes endured child neglet or even domestic violence when they were young.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘There are fewer and fewer types of antibiotics that can eliminate malignant bacteria, which is bad news for patients enduring illness.ã€åˆä½œã€‘Consistent goals, mutual support and active communication among team members can make teamwork endure.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘Those who have endured hardships can see setbacks in a positive light and make every effort to overcome them.
2. erode-If someoneâ€™s authority, right, or confidence erodes or is eroded, it is gradually destroyed or removed.Eg. America's believe in its own God-ordained uniqueness started to erode.
    His behaviour over the last few months has eroded my confidence in his judgment.
    Our personal freedom is being gradually eroded away. ã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘Without guidance from parents and teachers, childrenâ€™s confidence can easily be eroded by difficulties, which will make them become frustrated, and eventually give up the goal.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘The widespread use of the Internet has given people more access to information and the right to speak, which can erode the authority of experts.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘Increasing green areas can effectively prevent soil erosion, thereby reducing dusty conditions and improving air quality.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘With the increasing exchanges between countries, traditional culture runs the risk of being eroded by foreign influences.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘The physical and mental development of young people is still not complete, which means that they are easily eroded by violent and sexual content on television or in movies.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘Excessive work pressure, high-calorie diets and irregular schedules are constantly eroding young peopleâ€™s physical and mental health.ã€åˆä½œã€‘Suspicion and prejudice are cancers that erode cooperation.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘Only by sticking to the right goals and resisting the erosion of laziness, inferiority and fear can we finally succeed.

title: English Writing 02
author: loving-English Anastasia
content:
drain, eliminate


How does the book look like?
How to get one?Buy it!


 Â´â—_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ Ù©( â€˜Ï‰â€™ )Ùˆ  get! _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _â—`
1. drain-1. If something drains you, it leaves you feeling physically and emotionally exhausted.Eg. My emotional turmoil had drained me.
    The long journey completely drained me.-2. If energy drains or is drained from you, you lose all energy and become very tired.Eg. As his energy drained away, his despair and worry grew.
    I can help resolve conflicts that drain energy.-3. If you say that something is a drain on an organizationâ€™s finances or resources, you mean that it costs the organization a large amount of money, and you do not consider that it is worth it.Eg. an ultra-modern printing plant, which has been a big drain on resources
    Fraud trials are often complex and have become an expensive drain on the public purse.-4. If you say that a countryâ€™s or a companyâ€™s resources or finances are drained, you mean that they are used or spent completelyEg. The state's finances have been drained by war.
    The company has steadily drained its cash reserves.ã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘People are worried that the rising trend of studying abroad in recent years will lead to a serious brain drain.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘Excessive use of mobile phones will drain us, making it difficult for us to focus on the task at hand.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘Many of the once wide rivers in this country are now drained, but the problem of water wastage has not been effectively addressed.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘In the past, people looked forward to traditional festivals because they could have big meals and nice clothes at the festivals. However, as peopleâ€™s income rises, the festivity surrounding festivals seems to drain.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘Adolescents who have had criminal experiences are often seen as a drain by their families because it is difficult to integrate them into society.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘Most job in the IT industry are physically exhausting and emotionally draining, and many IT workers suffer from sub-health as a result.ã€åˆä½œã€‘Vicious competition between team members, if left unchecked, will drain the team of its efficiency and enthusiasm.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘The impact that a failure will have on people depends on their personalities. If they always see the world in a negative light then a small failure can drain them.       
2. eliminate-To eliminate something, especially something you do not want or need, means to remove it completely.Eg. The Sex Discrimination Act has not eliminated discrimination in employment.
    If you think you may be allergic to a food or drink, eliminate it from your diet.
    A move towards healthy eating could help eliminate heart disease.
    We eliminated the possibility that it could have been an accident.
    The new system will eliminate the need for people to buy tickets from a ticket office.ã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘To eliminate educational inquality, we should first recognize the existence of it and then build different schools suitable for different groups of people.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘Driverless technology eliminates the need for people to concentrate on driving for long periods of time.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘We can eliminate water pollution by setting quality standards, monitoring water quality and strenthening regulation.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘Traditional culture should be treated with a critical eye. We should eliminate traditional cultural practices that lag behind the times, and appreciate those show true value.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘There is no way of eliminating juvenile delinquency, but a stable social environment can effectively keep it at bay.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘Eliminating greasy food from your diet can help you stay health.ã€åˆä½œã€‘By praising the efforts and achievements of team members, we can eliminate their pressure and frustration.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘We should face up to the obstacles to success, stay confident and develop the ability to eliminate them.

title: English Writing 01
author: loving-English Anastasia
content:
blind, demand


Through wechat public account, I get a rather nice book, which is called â€œ100 words break through English writingâ€. For a more comprehensive and profound understanding, I manage to post it online by typing on my own. Thereâ€™s no doubt a great decision if it helps not only me but you.
How does the book look like?
How to get one?Buy it!


 Â´â—_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ Ù©( â€˜Ï‰â€™ )Ùˆ  get! _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _â—`
1. blind-If something blinds you to the real situation, it prevents you from realizing that it exists or from understanding it properly.Eg. He never allowed his love of Australia to blind him to his countrymenâ€™s faults.
    We mustnâ€™t let our prejudices blind us to the facts of the situation.ã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘We must not let the pursuit of test scores blind childrenâ€™s curiosity about the world.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘The virtual world has turned us into â€œphubbersâ€, blinding us to this colorful world.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘Although these environmentally damaging practices are unlikely to cause harm in a short period of time, it is for this reason that we are blinded and eventually fall into deep remorse.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘As technology develops, we begin to feel that we are capable  of anything, but this kind of thinking will blind us and make us unwilling to attach importance to historical experience.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘Many young people are blinded by some violent movies, thinking that violence is cool.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘Many people are blinded by some misconceptions, believing that their health relies on taking medicine, rather than regular eating habits and moderate exercise.ã€åˆä½œã€‘Sometimes we are blinded by intense competition and become short-sighted, but in fact, cooperation and competition can coexist.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘ When a person suddenly achieves great success, he or she is often blinded, not seeing the risks ahead.
2. demand-1. If one thing demands another, the first needs the second in order to happen or be dealt with successfully.Eg.  He said the task of reconstruction would demand much patience, hard work and sacrifice.
     But he could also turn on the style when the occasion demanded.-2. A demand is a firm request for something.Eg. There have been demands for services from tenants up there.
    They consistently rejected the demand to remove US troops.
    He grew ever more fierce in his demands.-3. If you refer to demands, or to the demand for something, you are referring to how many people want to have it, do it, or buy it.Eg. Demand for coal is down and so are prices.
    The demand to see her work is much greater than expected.
    Because of the slump in domestic demand, production has stopped.-4. If someone or something is in demand or in great demand, they are very popular and a lot of people want them.Eg. He was much in demand as a lecturer in the US.-5. If someone or something makes demands on you, they require you to do things which need a lot of time, energy, or money.Eg. I had no right to make demands on his time.ã€æ•™è‚²ã€‘You canâ€™t give in to childrenâ€™s demands all the time. It is better to let them earn what they want by doing some household chores.ã€ç§‘æŠ€ã€‘Making scientific breakthroughs would demand much patience, hard work and sacrifice.ã€ç¯å¢ƒã€‘Protecting the environment demands the active cooperation of all countries, and they should abide by the carbon credit system while supervising each other.ã€ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–‡åŒ–ã€‘Contrary to public belief, traditional cultural elements such as clothing and music are much in demand among young people.ã€é’å°‘å¹´çŠ¯ç½ªã€‘As the crime rate rises, there have been increased demands placed on public officers.ã€å¥åº·ã€‘Cleaning your teeth is not that difficult, but sticking to it is the most difficult part. Good dental hygiene demands constant efforts, and failing to keep your month clean will make you suffer from poor oral health.ã€åˆä½œã€‘Efficient teamwork demands each team member share their ideas as much as possible and do their best to achieve the common goal.ã€æˆåŠŸã€‘If you demand more from yourself than anyone else could ever except, then no one can ever stop you from realizing your dreams.
